awd_titl_txt: CoPe EAGER: Improving the financial recovery from coastal disasters: The role of innovative risk transfer instruments
awd_abstract_narration:
The risk of coastal flooding has been growing due to the combined effects of sea level rise, changing storm patterns, increased development, erosion, and in some places, subsidence. Since many of these risks are uninsured, they could have significant financial consequences for the nation and jeopardize the resilience of coastal communities. This project examines whether innovations to insurance marketplaces can produce better outcomes. Work on this project will include synthesis reviews; exploratory and testing workshops; semi-structured interviews; and deep case analysis of analog programs. This effort will draw on best practices for qualitative research to solve "grand challenges" and "wicked problems" and engage multiple sectors in co-creation of research and outcomes. This work will contribute to our broad understanding of risk transfer instruments and their role in community resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As the climate continues to warm, the risks in coastal communities from flooding, storms, and sea-level rise continues to escalate. Our tools to finance the recovery from coastal extremes, and to finance risk reduction as part of that recovery, are not currently suited to the magnitude of the problem. Gaps in financial recovery from coastal extremes jeopardize the resilience of coastal households and communities. There is the possibility, however, for innovative risk transfer instruments to address some of the existing limitations. To do so, however, a new approach to research, policy design, and public-private collaboration is required. This project was designed to be boundary spanning across research and practice to push forward both academic understanding of risk transfer approaches and improve the design and use of risk transfer tools for improved disaster risk management.

This project explored four innovative risk transfer approaches for coastal communities: (1) parametric microinsurance for more equitable recoveries; (2) insuring coastal ecosystems against destruction by the very events for which they provide community resilience; (3) community use of risk transfer both on behalf of residents and to manage its own financial impacts; and (4) homeowners insurance policies that could pay for retreat in the event of total property loss. While there has been discussion among academics and practitioners about such innovative tools, none are in operation in the U.S. (with the exception of microinsurance, which became available in Puerto Rico during this project). This project aimed to undertake the research and collaborative engagement necessary to design implementable, scalable, sustainable, and economically viable approaches in these four domains.

To achieve this objective, the project involved a core team at the Wharton Risk Center working under the guidance of an advisory board with members from multiple sectors and geographic areas. The project was launched with an initial scoping workshop bringing together researchers and practitioners. The research drew on best practice for qualitative methods from social science, including synthesis reviews, semi-structured interviews, and case analysis of analog programs. The semi-structured interviews were a key part of the research as they were necessary for uncovering hard-to-measure concepts for which data is unavailable. Interviewees were selected through a theoretical sampling procedure, where the emerging concepts and framework adaptively guided selection of additional interviewees. Coastal adaptation can be considered a societal “grand challenge” of the coming years: it is complex, impacts multiple entities, has interconnected components, is characterized by uncertainty, can be approached and described in multiple ways, and requires crossing boundaries. For these types of challenges, scholars have noted that inductive methods can be particularly useful, pulling insights from case analysis and interviews, deep immersion in a topic, rich qualitative and quantitative data analysis, and theme identification driven by problem solving.

The research outputs from this project contribute to a broader understanding of risk transfer instruments and their role in climate resilience. While prior research has evaluated traditional insurance and examined the role of insurance in recovery, there has been very little work to support the emergence of novel public-private partnerships for financing escalating disaster risk. This project began to fill that gap and expanded scholarly work on disaster risk transfer, focusing on research steeped in the institutional realities of practice.

This project was also designed to create deeper partnerships between researchers and practitioners and inform on-the-ground policy and practice. Working with several public sector partners, the project launched new collaborations, as well as at least one pilot. These partnerships are continuing beyond the end of this grant and are a measure of the project successfully creating lasting impact. This project launched the creation a community of practice around harnessing risk transfer for coastal resilience that will continue to advance this area of both research and practice.
